Short communication Facile synthesis of α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles and their catalytic activity in oxidation of benzyl alcohols with periodic acid Bappi Paul Bishal Bhuyan Debraj Dhar Purkayastha ⁎ Siddhartha Sankar Dhar ⁎ Department of Chemistry, National Institute of Technology Silchar, Silchar 788010 Assam, India Department of Chemistry National Institute of Technology Silchar Silchar Assam 788010 India ⁎ Corresponding authors. α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles (NPs) were synthesized by homogeneous chemical precipitation followed by calcination. Size-tuning of NPs was achieved by using polyethylene glycol with a molecular weight of 400 and 4000 as surfactant. Synthesized α-Fe2O3 NPs were characterized by powder XRD, transmission electron microscopy, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and vibrating sample magnetometry. These α-Fe2O3 NPs were used as magnetically recoverable catalyst in oxidation of benzyl alcohols to aldehydes with periodic acid. The catalyst showed higher efficiency with decrease in their sizes. Graphical abstract Keywords α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles Polyethylene glycol Size-tuning Magnetically recoverable catalyst 1 Introduction Magnetic nanoparticles are explored extensively as catalysts or catalyst supported materials owing to their high thermal and mechanical stability [1]. Their paramagnetic nature and inherent insolubility in reaction solvents make them ideal for simple and efficient separation by external magnetic field. Hematite (α-Fe2O3) is one of the most studied iron oxide nanomaterials due to their variety of applications such as in catalysis [2], pigments [3], gas sensors [4], lithium ion batteries [5] etc. Controlled growth of these NPs is critical for understanding and exploiting their unique properties. One of the simplest and most efficient methods of preparation of iron oxide NPs is homogeneous precipitation. The precipitation method is advantageous as it produces large amount of materials; however, control on particle size is limited unless some suitable surfactant is used. Polyethylene glycol (PEG) with uniform and ordered chain structure can act as a very useful surfactant to control size and morphology of the nanomaterials [6]. The chemical precipitation method often requires a base as hydrolyzing agent. Hexamine, a highly water-soluble, non-ionic tertiary amine derivative has gained popularity as hydrolyzing agent and plays a variety of roles in nanomaterial synthesis such as shape-inducing capping molecule, reducing agent and also known to assist anisotropic growth of metal oxides including Fe3O4 NPs [7]. Benzaldehyde is the expected product from partial oxidation of benzyl alcohols. Earlier carbon nanotube (CNT)-supported ruthenium and CNT-TiO2 nanohybrids were employed as catalysts for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohols with oxygen or air as oxidant [8,9]. Shi et al. utilized bulk as well as nano Fe2O3 as catalysts for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohols with hydrogen peroxide as oxidant [2,10]. However, nano α-Fe2O3 has not been explored extensively as catalyst, particularly in oxidation of benzyl alcohols with periodic acid. Periodic acid is a cheap, non-toxic, efficient oxidant known to be used in catalytic oxidation of alcohols including benzyl alcohols [11]. As a continuation of our recent endeavor [12] on synthesis and application of nanomaterials, we report herein, a new method of synthesis of α-Fe2O3 NPs and their catalytic activity in oxidation of benzyl alcohols to aldehydes with periodic acid. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and physical measurements Ferric nitrate, hexamine, PEG 400 and PEG 4000 were purchased from Merck India Ltd. Double distilled water was used throughout the experiment. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in air on a Netzsch STA449F3 thermal analyzer at a flow rate of 20mL/min and a heating rate of 10°C/min. FT-IR spectrum was recorded on KBr matrix with Bruker 3000 Hyperion Microscope with Vertex 80 FT-IR system. XRD measurements were carried out on a Bruker AXS D8-Advance powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.5418Å) with a scan speed of 2°/min. Transmission electron microscopy images were obtained on a JEOL, JEM2100 equipment. The sample powders were dispersed in ethanol under sonication and TEM grids were prepared using a few drops of dispersion followed by drying in air. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained with a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 surface area and porosity analyzer. Magnetism of the material was studied using a Lakeshore VSM 7410 at 27°C. 2.2 Synthesis of α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles Fe(NO)3·9H2O (0.80g, 2mmol) and hexamine (1.40g, 10mmol) were dissolved separately in minimum volume of distilled water. The resultant solutions were then mixed together and stirred magnetically for 4h. The reddish suspension thus formed was collected and dried in a hot air oven. The as-obtained precursor powder was then calcined in a muffle furnace for 4h at 550°C to obtain powder of α-Fe2O3. 2.3 Synthesis of α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles in presence of PEG Fe(NO)3·9H2O (0.80g, 2mmol) and hexamine (1.40g, 10mmol) were dissolved separately in minimum volume of distilled water. The resultant solutions were then mixed together and stirred magnetically followed by addition of 5mmol of surfactant PEG 400 or PEG 4000. After stirring for 4h, the reddish suspension was collected and dried in a hot air oven. The as-obtained precursor powder was then calcined in a muffle furnace for 4h at 550°C to obtain powder of α-Fe2O3. 2.4 Oxidation of benzyl alcohol In a typical procedure, catalyst (4mol%) and periodic acid (1.5mmol/3 equiv) were stirred with 10ml of water taken in a RB flask. The substrate (0.5mmol/1 equiv) was added slowly to the stirred solution/suspension. Stirring continued for required time at room temperature until complete conversion was achieved. The catalyst was then separated magnetically from the reaction mixture. The product was extracted with diethyl ether and purified by column chromatography using n-hexane: ethanol (4:1) as eluent to give the aldehyde. The separated catalyst was washed with ethanol and dried in a hot air oven. 3 Results and discussion In the present study, hematite (α-Fe2O3) nanoparticles have been synthesized by calcination of a ferric hydroxide (Fe(OH)3) precursor obtained by a homogeneous chemical precipitation method. Here, hydroxide anions are produced by hydration of hexamine, which cause a uniform rise in pH of the solution till the solubility limit thereby preventing the occurrence of high local supersaturation and allowing nucleation to occur homogeneously throughout the solution. The reactions involved in the formation of α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles are believed to be as follows: (1) CH 2 6 N 4 + 6 H 2 O → 4 NH 3 + 6 HCHO (2) NH 3 + H 2 O → NH 4 + + OH ‐ (3) Fe 3 + + 3 OH ‐ → Fe OH 3 (4) 2 Fe OH 3 → Δ Fe 2 O 3 + 3 H 2 O . The surfactant PEG was added to the precursor solution to control the particle size as well as size distribution of the nanoparticles. The synthesized ferric hydroxide precursor was characterized by TGA and FTIR. α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles were characterized by powder XRD, TEM, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and VSM. The TGA of the precursor synthesized in presence of PEG 400 was carried out as a representative case. The TGA curve (Fig. 1(a)) shows a two step decomposition pathway. The weight loss of 8.04% in the first step (30–100°C) is due to the removal of physically adsorbed moisture in the precursor. The weight loss of 79.67% in the second step (280–520°C) indicated removal of surfactant PEG 400 and subsequent conversion of Fe(OH)3 to α-Fe2O3. About 7% of the sample escaped without pyrolysis. FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 1(b)) showed O–H stretching at around 3400cm−1. Band at 2830cm−1 arose due to stretching vibrations of methylene group and strong bands in the range of 1000–1245 cm−1 may be attributed to C–O and C–C stretching vibrations [13]. Band at 1105cm−1 corresponds to C–O–C stretching vibrational mode [14]. This confirms the presence of surfactant PEG on the surface of Fe(OH)3 precursor. The powder XRD patterns (Fig. 1(c)) were recorded for the identification of phases. The diffraction peaks match well with the reported data of α-Fe2O3 (JCPDS File no. 87–1166). α-Fe2O3 possess a rhombohedrally centered hexagonal structure of the corundum type with a close-packed oxygen lattice in which two thirds of the octahedral sites are occupied by Fe(III) ions [15]. The TEM image of α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles (Fig. S1 in ESI) synthesized without surfactant showed some irregular shaped particles of size 50–100nm. The nanoparticles synthesized in presence of PEG 400 (Fig. 2 ) showed some quasi-spherical particles of size 10–50nm. The lattice fringes are separated by 0.252nm, which corresponds to the (110) plane of α-Fe2O3. Electron diffraction (ED) pattern indicated polycrystalline nature. The nanoparticles synthesized in presence of PEG 4000 (Fig. 3 ) also showed some quasi-spherical particles of size 5–20nm. The lattice fringes are separated by 0.251nm, which corresponds to the (110) plane of α-Fe2O3. ED pattern indicated single crystalline nature. Thus surfactant PEG played a crucial role in controlling the particle size as well as size distribution. Moreover, when PEG of high molecular weight i.e. PEG 4000 was used nanoparticles so formed are comparatively well dispersed with much smaller size. The TEM image of the nanoparticles recovered after five cycles (Fig. S2 in ESI) did not show much difference in sizes, shapes and morphology. N2 adsorption–desorption measurements were conducted to determine the Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) specific surface area of α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles synthesized in presence of PEG 400 and PEG 4000. Physical parameters of the materials obtained by means of N2 adsorption–desorption study are summarized in Table 1 . From Table 1 it can be noted that, α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles synthesized in presence of PEG 4000 possess high specific surface area and pore volume. The amount of N2 adsorbed rose gradually at lower relative pressures and then increased sharply at higher relative pressures (Fig. 4(a) and (b)). This follows the characteristics of a type IV isotherm with a type H3 hysteresis loop associated with aggregates of plate-like particles forming slit-like pores [16]. The hysteresis loop shifts to a higher relative pressure on approaching P/P0 =1, suggesting the presence of macropores and a low degree of aggregation [16], which was also confirmed by TEM images (Figs. 2 and 3). The Barrett Joyner Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution indicated that most of the pores range from 3 to 50nm (inset of Fig. 4(a) and (b)), which further confirmed the loose structures and a low degree of aggregation. The magnetic hysteresis measurement (Fig. 4(c)) of α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles synthesized in presence of PEG 4000 was done at 27°C with the applied magnetic field sweeping from −20,000 to +20,000G. The magnetic hysteresis loops showed a ferromagnetic behavior with a remnant magnetization (Mr) of 8.63emug−1 and coercivity (Hc) of 312.07G. The catalytic potential of as-synthesized α-Fe2O3 NPs was investigated in the oxidation of a few chosen substituted benzyl alcohols with periodic acid. For this purpose, benzyl alcohol was chosen as the model substrate. α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles synthesized in presence of PEG 4000 showed greatest catalytic efficiency in terms of yield and reaction time (Fig. 5(a)). The results are summarized in Table 2 . Best results were obtained when catalyst amount is 4mol% and substrate to oxidant ratio is 1:3. The yield of aldehyde in uncatalyzed reaction is very poor after a long reaction time. After every single catalytic run, the ferromagnetic α-Fe2O3 catalyst was magnetically separated, recovered and reused up to five times without any significant loss of activity (Fig. 5(b)). It was observed that although selectivity remains almost constant but yield of the products decrease slightly with the number of recycles. The oxidation reaction possibly followed the M-v K type mechanism [17]. The catalytic path involves two successive steps. At first α-Fe2O3 is reduced by benzyl alcohols, leading to the formation of aldehydes and reduced catalysts. This step includes the transfer of lattice oxygen atoms and the reduction of α-Fe2O3. Subsequently, the reduced catalysts are re-oxidized by oxygen produced from decomposition of periodic acid, replenishing oxygen back to the lattice. The plausible reaction mechanism is shown in Fig. S3 in ESI. 4 Conclusion In summary, a new approach to synthesis of hematite, α-Fe2O3 NPs is demonstrated. Calcination of hydroxylated iron(III) with PEG 4000 resulted in NPs with smallest size. These α-Fe2O3 NPs with or without PEG modification are all catalytically active and magnetically recoverable. However, PEG 4000 modified nano α-Fe2O3 exhibited highest efficiency for the oxidation of benzyl alcohols with periodic acid. The present catalytic protocol is simple and efficient with advantage of easy recovery and recyclability of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles (NPs) were synthesized by homogeneous chemical precipitation followed by calcination. Size-tuning of NPs was achieved by using polyethylene glycol with a molecular weight of 400 and 4000 as surfactant. Synthesized α-Fe2O3 NPs were characterized by powder XRD, transmission electron microscopy, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and vibrating sample magnetometry. These α-Fe2O3 NPs were used as magnetically recoverable catalyst in oxidation of benzyl alcohols to aldehydes with periodic acid. The catalyst showed higher efficiency with decrease in their sizes.
coredata.dc:title: Facile synthesis of α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles and their catalytic activity in oxidation of benzyl alcohols with periodic acid
